dt: {bc}an early vertebrate embryo which follows the gastrula and in which nervous tissue begins to differentiate and the basic pattern of the vertebrate begins to emerge

et: borrowed from New Latin (in a French context), "cluster of embryonic cells in marine gastropods that develop into the nervous system and eyes," from Greek {it}neûron{/it} "sinew, tendon, nerve" + New Latin {it}-ula{/it} (in {it}gastrula{/it} {et_link|gastrula|gastrula}) {ma}{mat|nerve:1|}{/ma}

Term apparently introduced by the Swiss embryologist Hermann Fol (1845-92) in "Sur le dèveloppement des hétéropodes," {it}Comptes rendus hebdomadaires des séances de l'Académie des Sciences,{/it} tome 81 (juillet-décembre 1875), pp. 472-74. In reference to vertebrate embryology the word was employed later by the German embryologist August Rauber (1841-1917) in {it}Primitivstreifen und Neurula der Wirbelthieren, in normaler und pathologischer Beziehung{/it} (Leipzig, 1877).
shortdef: an early vertebrate embryo which follows the gastrula and in which nervous tissue begins to differentiate and the basic pattern of the vertebrate begins to emerge
